com.fidelis.valface

Class ADate

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.fidelis.valface.ADate
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<ADate>

    public class ADate
extends Object
implements Comparable<ADate>
    Implements a date class based on the proleptic Gregorian Calendar. A date of this type extends the rules of the Gregorian Calendar to the time prior to it's development. To paraphrase the rules:
    • A year is divided into 12 months.
    • A month is divided into a number of days that correspond with each month.
    • The month of February (2) has 28 days except on a leap year when it has 29 days.
    • A leap year occurs every 4th year with exceptions.
    • Every 100th year is not a leap year with exceptions.
    • Every 400th year is a leap year.
    The year 1900 is not a leap year but the year 2000 is. The years 2004, 2008, and 2012 are leap years. All months, other than February, have a fixed number of days. All years are made up of 365 days unless it is a leap year which has 366.

    This class has components for the year, the month and the day that make up the date. The year is a positive number with a range that begins with 0 and is limited to 9999. The month component goes from 1 for January to 12 for December. The day value must be in a valid range for the corresponding month. In particular, the month of February (2) will have 28 days unless it is a leap year in which case it has 29.

    At the time of this writing, Java SE 8 is a few months away from being officially released. This release will include a similar class LocalDate that serves as a model for this version. Central to this idea is that a date be immutable. Once a date has been created with one of the factory methods, it's value can not be changed. Any modifications such as the with and plus methods generate a new date.

    Version:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Leo Hinterlang

    • Method Detail

      • now

        public static ADate now()
        Produces an instance of ADate that is set to the current date. The current date is retrieved from the system and used to set the year, month and day components.
        Returns:
        a new instance of ADate representing the current date.

      • nowTestSet

        public static void nowTestSet(ADate now)
        Used only for testing, sets a particular date as the value for "now". To restore normal operation, use the nowTestClear method.
        Parameters:
        now - the date to set for testing
        See Also:
        nowTestClear()

      • nowTestClear

        public static void nowTestClear()
        Used only for testing, clears the fixed date value used for "now". This resets the test condition initiated by the nowTestSet method.
        See Also:
        nowTestSet(com.fidelis.valface.ADate)

      • of

        public static ADate of(int year,
       int month,
       int day)
                throws IllegalArgumentException
        Produces an instance of ADate from a year, month and day. This static method creates a new date represented by the components for the year, the month and the day of the month. The year must be a positive value in the range 0 to 9999. The month must be the number of the month starting with 1 for January up to 12 for December. The day must be in the valid range for the given year and month. In particular, February 29 is only valid in a leap year.
        Parameters:
        year - the year component from 0 to 9999.
        month - the month component in the range 1 to 12.
        day - the day of the month component from 1 to 31 depending on the year and month.
        Returns:
        a new instance of ADate.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if any of the components are found to be invalid.

      • of

        public static ADate of(ADate aDate)
        Produces an instance of ADate from another ADate. The year, month and day components are set identical to the specified date.
        Parameters:
        aDate - the date that provides the component values for the new date.
        Returns:
        a new instance of ADate with the same values.

      • parse

        public static ADate parse(String dateString)
                   throws IllegalArgumentException
        Produces an instance of ADate from the specified String. The date String takes the form YEARMODA where YEAR is a 4 digit year number, MO is a 2 digit month number, and DA is a 2 digit day number. Two alternative forms allow these 3 fields to be separated by dashes or by dots. With the field separators, the leading zero for month and day are not required. In all cases, the year is specified first, then the month and day.

        If the parsed String is not in the proper form or a value for a component is invalid, no values will be set and an exception is thrown.

        Examples: 

         ADate.parse("20130308");  // March 8, 2013
 ADate.parse("2000-1-1");  // January 1, 2000
 ADate.parse("1941.12.7"); // December 7, 1941
        Parameters:
        dateString - the String that specifies the date components.
        Returns:
        a new instance of ADate.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified date String is not valid.

      • getYear

        public int getYear()
        Returns the year component of the date.
        Returns:
        the year number (0 .. 9999).

      • withYear

        public ADate withYear(int year)
               throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the year changed to the value specified. If the day of the month becomes invalid due to this change, it will be adjusted to the last valid day of the month.
        Parameters:
        year - the year number (0 .. 9999).
        Returns:
        an ADate with the year value changed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the year is not valid.

      • withMonth

        public ADate withMonth(int month)
                throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the month changed to the value specified. If the day of the month becomes invalid due to this change, it will be adjusted to the last valid day of the month.
        Parameters:
        month - the month number (1 .. 12).
        Returns:
        an ADate with the month value changed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the month is invalid.

      • withDay

        public ADate withDay(int day)
              throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the day of the month changed to the value specified. If the day of the month is invalid for the year and month of this date, an exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        day - the day of the month (1 .. 31).
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance with the day of the month changed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the day is invalid.

      • plusYears

        public ADate plusYears(int years)
                throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the specified number of years added to it. If the resulting date is outside the valid date range, an exception is thrown. If the year change results in going from a leap year to a standard year, the day component may be adjusted from February 29th to the 28th.
        Parameters:
        years - the number of years to add. Negative values can be used to achieve subtraction.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance with the modified date.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the resulting date is not valid.

      • plusMonths

        public ADate plusMonths(int months)
                 throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the specified number of months added to it. The addition will affect both the month and year components to maintain a valid date. If the resulting date is invalid, an exception is thrown. This will only occur if the year falls outside the range 0 to 9999. As with the withMonth method, the day component may be adjusted due to a change in the month.
        Parameters:
        months - the number of months to be added. Negative values can be used to achieve subtraction.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance with the modified date.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the resulting date is not valid.

      • plusDays

        public ADate plusDays(int days)
               throws IllegalArgumentException
        Returns a copy of this date with the specified number of days added to it. The year, month and day components may all be modified as a result of this addition. If the resulting date is invalid, an exception is thrown. This will only occur if the year falls outside the range 0 to 9999.
        Parameters:
        days - the number of days to be added. Negative values can be used to achieve subtraction.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance with the date modified.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the resulting date is not valid.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(ADate other)
        Compares this date with another date to determine if they are equal. The year, month and day components of this date are compared with those of the specified "other" date. If they are the same, then true is returned.
        Parameters:
        other - the date to be compared with this one.
        Returns:
        true if the dates are equal, false otherwise.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(ADate other)
        Compares this date with another date. This date is compared with the "other" date to determined if the "other" is less than, greater than, or equal to this one. This relation is presented as a return value that is either less than, greater than, or equal to zero.

        This method implements the Comparable interface so that dates can be sorted.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<ADate>
        Parameters:
        other - the date to compare with this one.
        Returns:
        an integer that is either less than, greater than, or equal to zero.
        See Also:
        Comparable.compareTo(java.lang.Object)

      • valueOf

        public static ADate valueOf(int days)
        Produces a new ADate instance from the number of days since the start of the timeline. January 1, 0000 is day number 1. This is identical to the fromDays method. To determine the number of days in a date, use the getDays or the intValue method.
        Parameters:
        days - the number of days since the start of the timeline.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance.

      • intValue

        public int intValue()
        Returns the number of days that this date represents since the start of the timeline. This is identical to the getDays method. To produce a new ADate instance from this value, use the valueOf method or the fromDays method.
        Returns:
        the number of days since the start of this timeline.

      • valueOf

        public static ADate valueOf(String dateString)
                     throws IllegalArgumentException
        Produces a new ADate instance from the specified String. The valid date forms are "yearmoda", "year-mo-da", or "year.mo.da". This is identical to the parse method.
        Parameters:
        dateString - the String specification for the date.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the specified date String is not valid.

      • valueOf

        public static ADate valueOf(ADate aDate)
        Produces a new ADate instance from another ADate. The year, month, and day components from the specified date are used to produce the new date with the same values. This is identical to the of method.
        Parameters:
        aDate - the date that provides the year, month, and day for the new date.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance.

      • isLeapYear

        public boolean isLeapYear()
        Determines if this date is in a leap year. A leap year occurs every 4 years unless the year is evenly divisible by 100 and not evenly divisible by 400. Thus 1900 is not a leap year but 2000 is.
        Returns:
        true if the year component for this date is a leap year.

      • isLeapYear

        public static boolean isLeapYear(int year)
        Determines if the given year is a leap year. A leap year occurs every 4 years unless the year is evenly divisible by 100 but not evenly divisible by 400. Thus 1900 is not a leap year but 2000 is.
        Parameters:
        year - the year to be checked.
        Returns:
        true if the indicated year is a leap year.

      • lengthOfMonth

        public int lengthOfMonth()
        Returns the number of days for this date's month. Thirty days for September, April, June, and November. Thirty-one for January, March, May, July, August, October, and December. February has 28 in a standard year and 29 in a leap year.
        Returns:
        the number of days in this date's month.

      • lengthOfMonth

        public static int lengthOfMonth(int year,
                int month)
        Returns the number of days in the specified month and year. The year is necessary to determine if February has 28 or 29 days based on the leap year calculation.
        Parameters:
        year - the year number.
        month - the month number.
        Returns:
        the number of days in the month.

      • lengthOfYear

        public int lengthOfYear()
        Returns the number of days in this date's year. If it is a leap year, the number is 366. If it is a standard year, the number is 365.
        Returns:
        the number of days in this date's year.

      • lengthOfYear

        public static int lengthOfYear(int year)
        Returns the number of days in the specified year. If the year is a leap year, the number is 366. If the year is a standard year, the number is 365.
        Parameters:
        year - the year number.
        Returns:
        the number of days in the year.

      • monthName

        public String monthName()
        Returns the name for the month. The months are numbered from 1 to 12 and correspond with the names January through December. This form is also known as FULL in the enumeration TextStyle (Java 8).
        Returns:
        the name for the month.

      • mon

        public String mon()
        Returns an abbreviated, 3 character name for the month. The months are numbered from 1 to 12 and correspond with the names Jan through Dec. This form is also known as SHORT in the enumeration TextStyle (Java 8).
        Returns:
        the abbreviated 3 character name for the month.

      • dowName

        public String dowName()
        Returns the name for the day of the week. The days of the week are numbered from 1 to 7 and correspond with the names Monday through Sunday. This form is also known as FULL in the enumeration TextStyle (Java 8).

        As it says in the Bible:

        "On the seventh day God rested from all his works."
        Returns:
        the name for the day of the week.

      • dow

        public String dow()
        Returns an abbreviated, 3 character name for the day of the week. The days of the week are numbered from 1 to 7 and correspond with the names Mon through Sun. This form is also known as SHORT in the enumeration TextStyle (Java 8).

        As it says in the Bible:

        "On the seventh day God rested from all his works."
        Returns:
        the abbreviated 3 character name for the day of the week.

      • format

        public String format(String pattern)
        Formats the date based on pattern keywords. The pattern is scanned for keywords that are replaced by the indicated value or text. The valid keywords include the following:
        • Year - the year number.
        • Month - the month number.
        • Day - the day number.
        • year - 4 digit year number.
        • yr - 2 digit year without the century digits.
        • month - 2 digit month number with leading zero when needed.
        • mo - same as month.
        • day - 2 digit day number with leading zero when needed.
        • da - same as day.
        • monthName - full month name as in September.
        • mon - abbreviated, 3 character month name as in Sep.
        • dowName - day of the week name as in Tuesday.
        • dow - abbreviated, 3 character day of the week name as in Tue.
        • days - the number of days that this date represents in the timeline.

        Other characters appearing in the pattern are copied without translation. To protect text that may contain segments that make up a keyword, place the text between angle brackets as in <more text>.

        Examples:

        today.format("year-mo-da"); 2013-03-08
        today.format("<Month: >monthName"); Month: March
        today.format("<Today is: >dowName"); Today is: Friday
        today.format("mon Day, year dow"); Mar 8, 2013 Fri
        Parameters:
        pattern - the format pattern.
        Returns:
        a formatted date String.

      • dayOfWeek

        public int dayOfWeek()
        Returns the day of the week as an integer. The days of the week are numbered from 1 for Monday to 7 for Sunday. Use dowName to obtain the day of the week name as a String or dow to get the short form of the name.
        Returns:
        the integer value from 1 (Monday) to 7 (Sunday).

      • getDays

        public int getDays()
        Returns the number of days since the start of this timeline. January 1, 0000 is day number 1. The year zero is considered a leap year with 366 days. Consistent time intervals can be achieved based on the number of days between dates.
        Returns:
        the number of days since the start of this timeline.

      • fromDays

        public static ADate fromDays(int days)
        Returns a new ADate instance from the number of days since the start of the timeline. The timeline begins with the year zero. January 1, 0000 is day number 1. Consistent time intervals can be achieved based on the number of days between dates.
        Parameters:
        days - the number of days since the start of the timeline.
        Returns:
        a new ADate instance generated from the number of days.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns this date in the form "year-mo-da". The year is 4 digits, the month is 2 digits, and the day is 2 digits. Use format to get other forms.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        the date String as in 2013-03-08.
        See Also:
        Object.toString()
